comments.text:
Update: As of 8:30pm Feb 18, ASUS reached out to confirm that the price of the "Base Prime Model" is $749. 

I cannot speak to the accuracy of the pricing Micro Center showed stating $899. 

Anyway, this is just more examples of how screwed up this entire 50 series family launch has been...

comments.text:
I don’t disagree with you, but value is relative and so is “expensive.” Most people wouldn’t pay 4x more for a $125k+ Audi station wagon over a Honda Accord, but people like you and I go absolutely bonkers over them. 

The market has spoken and these prices are absolutely justifiable for what they offer. 

Also, with inflation the way it has been, these $900 video cards are equivalent to what a $649 card was 10 years ago.

Hell, I paid $1000 for an FX-60 dual core CPU in 2006. That’s $1600 today!

comments.text:
I'm looking to upgrade my PC, it has a 7900X processor, TUF Gaming 4070 Ti OC and 64 GB of DDR5 6000MHz  RAM . When using Flight Sim I frequently run out of GPU memory with the CPU chugging along at about 30-40% and the GPU at 99% with warnings about GPU memory. When running VR I get about 45fps with stutters every now and then as the GPU memory runs out. On looking to see what component upgrade would give me the biggest boost, the answer is always GPU, the rest is working fine and any other upgrade only gives marginal improvement.

The 5070TI would give a small single digit percentage increase, 5080 a bit more but for a real improvement boost I would need to consider  the 5090, which I simply don't want to pay for. I guess I'm going to have to shave a bit more off the quality settings to remove the stutters but this defeats the 'improved' graphics potential of MSFS 2024 in VR (upgrade 2 makes quite a difference to the quality in vr).

Moving into the future I can see myself building two PCs; one optimised for AI and one for gaming, and long term I can see the industry adjusting. Nvidia will branch off its gaming and AI divisions and AMD might eat their lunch for a while. We're just in a transition period right now which is rough. PS5 Pro is not a solution lol... 4k, 120/144fps, HDR, is imo, the absolute optimal for gaming, it will never get better than this. 4k provides the perfect pixel density for the smoothest curves with absolutely no blur and no noticable pixels. 120/144fps are exactly the right amount of frames for smooth camera panning in games. HDR is just better than the oversaturated abomination of SDR that is constantly shoved into gamer's faces, it provides more depth and better contrasts without oversaturation.

PS5 Pro cannot do 4k 120/144fps and HDR together. It can do parts of this together, but it can't even do 4k 120 on any modern game... Unfortunately what I suspected for few years and what became pretty obvious when they postponed the 50 series by a year (forgotten what their excuse was but essentially it was to make more AI boards) seems to have been right on the money. I couldn't wrap my head around why NVIDIA would waste limited silicon wafer manufacturer slots/availability to make a GPU when the same amount of silicon would make them tens of thousands of dollars in an AI board.

The answer as far as my ill informed ignorant mind can tell is just to put the rubber stamp on their books to say that they still have a GPU business, probably looks good to shareholders even if it isn't where the money comes from and they might have something to fall back on if the rug gets pulled out from under of them on the AI market by someone else. 

Really gives you that warm and fuzzy feeling knowing that those NVIDIA Riva TNT 16's and 32's you bought in the 90's and all the many cards you bought personally and put into other builds helped create the behemoth NVIDIA is today, a behemoth that likes to crap all over it's original customer base.

comments.text: If these cards were truly AI focused, then they would put more VRAM on it. 16 Gb is a joke, most people doing local LLM stuff will buy a specific rig and buy two RTX 3090 for better offloading and VRAM usage, or 7900 XT, or the RTX 4090. Period. You are getting nowhere with 16 Gb, maybe just run Mistral 7Bx8, Nous-Capybara 34B why not, but not much more. For 70-120B Q4 KM and Q5 models you'll need high end (even if old gen) high VRAM cards. For GPU clusters it's A100 or H100 which are way beyond what consumers can realistically afford. And now you'll understand the problem: Meta is investing billions trying to get 500.000 GPUs and more in the future. That's just Meta, not OpenAI, not Google or anyone else who are also buying cards. Not mentioning the numerous smaller tech companies who propose AI services based on lower end LLMs but still make people pay subscriptions to use those open source freewares. Result: millions upon millions of GPUs are bought by these tech companies and I suspect they will also buy "consumer" cards when they can't get said A100 and H100, they are probably also scalping massively which doesn't help with Nvidia's forced artificial scarcity.

comments.text: I was originally looking for a RTX 5090 on launch day, but I was lucky enough to get a MSI RTX 5080 Ventus 3X OC for $1100 to replace my Gigabyte RTX 4080 Master. I'm seeing a 15~25% performance boost and it's extremely smooth where my 4080 use to jitter and stutter. It overclocks like a champ, plus I was able to sell my RTX 4080 for $1,300 (paid $900 for it in 2023) so it was a 'free' upgrade to me. I can play anything I want at 4K and I'm more than happy. IMHO, if you can find a RTX 5080, it's the better buy compared to a RTX 5090. It uses a lot less power (don't need more than a 850W PS), nearly RTX 4090 performance, generates a lot less heat, doesn't melt the power connector and plays everything perfectly at 4K. A lot of people bashed the 5080 but to me, it's the perfect balance of performance and power usage for the price - if you can find it at MSRP.

comments.text:
26:30 that was epic
 You know, i dont remember if in 2020 (could be 2022) i got the cheapest i found and even brand new, not used, 1650 (normal not super) for 20k argentinian pesos, back in that year that would be less than 20usd (the ratio was like 1usd = 800 pesos), can you believe it? a less than 20 dollars card. I felt very lucky because other cards were +45k $ and for some reason they had GDDR5 while mine had GDDR6. I was also very scared because it was from PNY a brand i never saw or heard about and the card is very modest, 2 small fans with no RGB or any of that silly bs. Still when i got it i plugged it in installed the drivers and felt in love, NEVER had a problem, a blue screen, a heat throttle, and never heard it at all through the headphones, it was like magic even when the card was pushed to its limits.
 The breaking point for upgrading it was the first MHWilds beta where everything looked like big pixel boxes but even then it was running it at 40-55 fps, not a single stutter, just the unfortunate graphic glitch. I did the whole chatacabra and dogashuma hunts in that way, mounting and stabbing a big red pixel was very funny, I was still happy.
 In last december i sold that card to a friend and he is as happy as i was and i got a rx7600, the cost was like 500k but i got it in discount for 485k (in dollars that is aproximately 485 coz the ratio nowadays fluctuates everyday but its 1usd=1k pesos on average). As you can see a quite huge price increase and a lot of money in my country.
 Well, am i happy with it at least after paying that price?: First of all it didnt give display the first time i plugged it in, i was already doing the proccess to return it after a day of trying when i said "one last try before putting it in the box", it randomly displayed images and started working, then i tested it and everything seemed fine until i started getting heat issues, i was planning to get a air conditioner anyways so well, i got one and that helped, i tried playing Dying light 2 -ramdonly crashes every 1 hour or doesnt crash at all-, i had to tweak stuff to make it work better and its still VERY loud under load (btw i looked at bios and found no parameters to change, tried to install Ryzen Master and it failed, looked tutorials and information and learned how to undervolt it in the Adrenalin app but if something crashes it puts everything to default and i have to tweak everything again), had to google and do some weird stuff to enable smart access memory. And lastly, this new card comes with new stuff like frame generation, super resolution, etc. I tested them and i ended up disabling everything because it looked smoother and better without them, so all those "new features" are worthless.
 So yeah, i wasnt happy at all, and after spending so much i still feel behind in tech than the rest of the world but at least MHWilds doesnt have the no-models bug anymore 

so tl;dr: pc gaming is already a rich man hobby, everything was better before or in other words, everything nowadays is shit and getting worse, dont buy this, you will get something better sooner or later

You know I was planning to upgrade - because I got a 240hz monitor.
I wanted to spent the money for a new GPU, but the 50 series is more than 30% above MSRP in Germany. Most card models are around 40% up. That's mind numbingly crazy.
I am really happy I got a 3090 close to release when it was not crazy inflated. This plus Lossless Scaling will enable me to hold out for new AMD cards. The 3090 was the first green card since the Geforce 256 (Elsa Erazor X) and what did NVIDIA do to keep me as a customer?
Increased price.
Limited features like DLSS and frame gen to newer cards artificially even though 3rd party software (Lossless Scaling) shows this can be done on the 30!
Increased price.
Added a burning connector.
Doubled down on the burning connector.
Dumbed down cards so that load balancing wires and individual wire fusing isn't a thing and this fire shit is even allowed to happen.
Borked drivers so people get black screens.

Wow.
Yeah I will switch back. Please AMD and also Intel get your shit together and smack NVIDIA down hard. NVIDIA can build AI. You give us payable gaming cards please.

Let me close with a quote from Linus Torvalds:
"NVIDIA: FUCK YOU!"

PS: Instead I upgraded my 5950X to a 9800X3D, lowered quality and got >50% more FPS.

comments.text:
8:05 - I'm sorry, what ? 20% is a normal GENERATIONAL improvement ? Dude... First of all, 5070 Ti replaces the 4070 Ti Super, not the regular 4070 Ti. That makes the perf uplift even smaller. Secondly, 20% is a good refresh uplift, not a good or normal generational uplift. A normal or average generational uplift from a bunch of previous gens is 30-40%. A good uplift is 50-60%. 20% is weak. It would have been good for a new CPU, not a new GPU. And since it's less than even the paltry 20%, because it should be compared to the 4070TiS, it's a total nothingburger. Why would you try to meatshield something so obviously weak ? Price and availibility are not the only bad things about the entire 50 series. Their perf uplift is on the level of a Super refresh, after more than 2 years. That's why they had to come up with MFG bullpoo and lie to people that a 5070 is equal to 4090 in perfromance. Even if the 50 series cards were availible AND at their MSRPs, they would have still been a boring, weak upgrade. This card in particular should have been the 5070, maybe even a 5060Ti. Then it would have been a good, exciting product.

10:35 - Acoustics, sure... I think they erred on the side of margins.

comments.text:
The real problem is that people still pay those stupidly high prices. If the cards get scalped, people still pay THOSE stupidly high prices. Why would nvidia or anybody else not charge the stupid high prices if the stupid consumers show they're more than happy to pay said stupidly high prices? To see any possible maybe change in the situation (which would still probably not happen, they don't care about consumers as stated) is for people to actually just not buy the cards. If they see that nobody is buying the cards, then maybe they might realize the pricing is off.

The true reason this all started is during the "shortages" (they were real, but not for anywhere near as long as people kept parroting) when scalpers were charging like 2 grand for a 3070 they were still selling cards just fine at those horrific prices. If the moronic consumers show that they're willing to still buy GPUs while being bent over horribly, then the people making the hardware to begin with aren't going to pass up the chance to massively inflate their margins. If people would have just not bought the overpriced GPUs like people weren't buying the overpriced scalped PS5 pros (leading to a lot being sold at a loss or even), we would be in a much better place right now for GPUs.

Thankfully, I have more fun pushing midrange and budget hardware, playing games at 1080p, 2560x1080, or 1440p. 4K is pointless on PC, just like how 4K in general is pointless for most people that pay twice or more for a 4k display and then throw on 125-150% scaling to make it a 1000 dollar or whatever 1440p display with worse specs. Is it better? Yes, but it's way past the point of diminishing returns. All the people that opted to go for 1440p displays and can happily lock fps at the monitor's native stupid high refresh rate will have fun without going bankrupt since any GPU for a while can generally handle that just fine (my RX6800XT still runs fine, but I'm still dropping it for a B770 if it comes out or a C770 in 2 years or so; if it breaks before then, hopefully I can find a B580 for 275 or so and happily play my games on full blast on my solid 2560x1080 setup).

I hope people listen to the reviews and dont buy it. I'm on my third review now and its all the same, recommend not to buy. But I bet they will all sell out because people will be out there saying that they can get 4090 performance in a 5070, so a 5070Ti should be faster than a 4090.

I hope 50 series stock rots on shelves... Not that this helps the smaller retailers at all, because then they are out of pocket, nvidia sells to AIBs and gets thier money, AIBs sell to distributors and get thier money, distributors sell to larger and smaller retailers (the largest resellers go direct to the AIBs), distributors make thier money leaving the reseller out of pocket if they happen to be a smaller reseller and cant sell the card once the AIBs start dropping prices and the small resellers dont qualify to be reimburst for the new lower cost price.

It really makes me wonder how far down the stack the melting connectors will go.

The gaming sector for nvidia is just lunch money now, but they are greedy so they want as much lunch money as they can get. Its complete bollocks, I understand it from a purely business sense, but people need to stop taking the crap and just let the stock rot on shelves. Just resist your urge to get a card with a 5 on the box and stick with what you have now. I'm still on the 5700XT, works fine for me on a 1440p display. I dont need anything better, I am considering grabbing a new AMD card or maybe even Intel card this gen, but just waiting to see what reviews and prices are like for the 9070XT since it will be my GPU until around 2029 at least. For me nvidia doesnt deserve my money and therefore they have been removed from my consideration list entirely until they stop the dodgey practices (so never). Now if only about 50% of gamers out there could do the same, next gen would be cheaper and better performance.

comments.text:
As for GDDR7X, I think it's unlikely that Micron will do it anytime soon. The benefits have diminished with each generation and the speed increase for GDDR6X already increased power consumption quite a bit despite PAM-4 signaling technically being more efficient. GDDR7 uses PAM-3 and is already running hot. The official spec lists up to 48 Gbps/pin as potentially available in the future.

GDDR7X would likely be quad data rate and require a pin count increase (like GDDR5X) to make it worth while and the necessary speeds would likely be a bit silly in terms of power consumption. I'm not even sure the on-die ECC (primarily there for machine learning) could deal with the signal integrity challenges.

comments.text:
Liked and subscribed

Thank you for this, gamer from 1979 living in Liverpool UK here.

Love how honest you are and that you had the sway to force an OEM to change their price, bravo to that, massive respect.

My last GPU i spent about £800 on it, it was an EVGA 1080sc and it was a monster at the time, i loved it and i didn't mind the price because it was rapid.

That died and i eventually got a 6070XT, didn't have a lot of money and still don't so  that was the best of a mid / low end bunch.

Now these 50 series cards are out, i honestly feel sick, they are ridiculously expensive and from what i can gather, not a single one is worth it.

I can play any single game i throw at my 6070XT in 1440p  and i'm fine with that.

For me if you want to fix this situation, talk with your wallet, right now if i had the money i would not spend it on nvidia, which pains me to say that but it's true, they just don't deserve it.

They lied about performance, they are melting GPU's again and they've lied about the price, plus they know by limiting stock it'll put the price up and create a buzz, to some people all the moaning doesn't matter if you have one in your rig.

Personally i'd rather give greedy green the finger and go with an XTX or even an XT from AMD, i wouldn't piss on any of the 50 series cards if they were on fire and theres a strong likelihood that that situation could happen.

What a disgusting time to be a PC gamer.

comments.text:
As an upgrade these don't seem worth it. But what if you are actually buying in from scratch? I am in the tricky position where I had a 3080 12gb and it was great, but the damn thing stopped working on me at the end of January. I'm running a backup Intel A770 (16gb model) and it's... surprisingly fine. But also a massive step backward performance-wise. 

Comparisons with 4080 Super, 4070 Ti etc are all very well and good but I don't have those cards and you can't buy those cards. Obviously there's no guarantee that the 5070 Ti would be any more obtainable but all other things being equal right now, the market is so depleted of any stock that if you're not willing to spend $1500+ on a 5080 it comes down to, buy a 7800 XT at maybe $600-700 or maybe snag one of the rare 7900 XTs or XTXs at $800-1000 if they come into stock ever (which is rare because I think AMD may have also ended production on these cards with the 9070 coming up). You're not going to get a 4080S, those are gone, production is ended and the remaining stock is being scalped for crazy prices. 

With that context. even at $950, the 5070 Ti starts looking a lot less terrible especially if you can snag one of the lower priced cards, since it is a marginal generational uplift over the 4070 Ti and it's outperforming the current AMD offerings. I don't like it but it does feel like it's probably the Compromise Card for my situation (FWIW I was set to stretch my budget to buy a 5080 at launch but they're unobtanium and the price hikes have put them well past where they look like they're worth it) unless I manage to snag a really amazing deal on a 7900 XTX or the 9070 XT is a performance monster and AMD somehow bucks the trend of the last 15 years or so and doesn't fuck up the launch somehow.

comments.text:
This won't change until consumer grade NPUs become a thing.  Right now most NVIDIA graphics cards are probably being purchased by people (mostly developers and tinkerers) wanting lots of local matrix multipliers for AI acceleration.  Many won't ever have a monitor connected (because you don't want to waste AI performance by having your high end graphics card waste cycles doing graphics!)

CUDA provides a ton of functionality that has close to zero value for AI, like integration engines for raytracing. 

But unfortunately, all the local PC workstation level AI stuff is primarily optimized for CUDA.

This will change.  Someone (maybe NVIDIA, maybe GROQ, maybe who-knows-who) will get serious about producing a dedicated PCIe NPU (which is kinda just the matrix-multiplying bits of a GPU, with maximum RAM) for end-user machines.

You can tell it's coming, because it's already being done by SoC vendors, and flagship phones with separate NPUs and GPUs are already appearing.

Until then, sorry gamers.  We don't want to be forced to compete with you in the market for expensive hardware that isn't even really optimized for what we  need it for, but it's still a lot more economical for us than the available data-center targeted server NPUs, that might not even work with the software we want to run locally. 

(Side note: as a potential trade-off, your existing graphics card might have a somewhat higher value on the second hand market than last time you looked)

comments.text: Jay, you couldn't have ended the video better. That is how just about ever PC gamer feels right now. However, why would AMD even bother trying to go against the grain? They tried that so many times before and it constantly bit them in the @. They said they wouldn't bother with RT until it was in more widespread use and viable from the top down to the bottom of the GPU stack, and reviewers beat them up every way they could for it even though they were giving 1080ti performance for $400. They released an upscaler that didn't just work on their new and older cards, but on the competition's cards new and old as well and reviewers constantly bashed them for it not being as good as DLSS while ignoring that DLSS was only available on Nvidia cards and more often than not the newer features were only available on their newest cards. Even with this release, AMD said they wanted to focus on the midrange where the majority of gamers exist and instantly before performance or pricing is even guessed at reviewers are throwing hate at AMD for letting Nvidia run loose at the high end with no competition. Before EVERY AMD/Radeon GPU video that I've watched since after the 5000 series release my first thought was always "well, let's see how this is going to turn into a giant dumpster fire this time.". Don't get me wrong AMD has done plenty to deserve their fair share of hate, but when so few reviewers looked at the things they attempted with only giving negative criticism and not pointing out the good parts it gives AMD no reason to put effort into something they are just going to get raked over the coals for. But, thats just my two cents.

comments.text:
Its because of the way the free market has been corrupted to serve not even the wealthy anymore, but the ULTRA rich, and no one else. And it probably won't change anytime soon barring some kind of economic collapse akin to the great depression. Governments not just in the USA (but obviously the USA is one of the better examples here) have been commandeered by individuals and corporations that want to inflate their wealth and nothing else. You can argue about the technical definitions of a plutocracy but America IS run by and for rich people. 

Wages have been stagnant for how many decades now? Regardless of what you think of some jobs, wages have to go up, people wouldn't be able to survive on wages that haven't changed since the 1950's for example. But wages aren't going to go up anytime soon for the majority because the people that own these companies also own the government to keep them stagnated. Even if you think working a retail job shouldn't pay enough to own a house, those people should at the very least have their wages keep up with inflation but that's not happening and hasn't for decades. The minimum wage where I live 20 years ago was $6.85 cents. Today It's a measly 10.70, not even enough to live in an apartment by yourself. Do you really think the people stocking your grocery store with food don't deserve to at least be able to comfortably afford rent in a cheap apartment?

All this to say that you are not wrong in feeling like everything is becoming a rich mans game (get it?) because it is. As the income disparity continues to get worse, things will slowly get more expensive while people gradually have less and less free income to spend. The pandemic was kind of the catalyst for this, except nobody was paying attention to fair pricing, people were too focused on vaccines to care, but that is when these companies started to get really greedy and inflate prices and it hasn't stopped. Everyone said prices would go back down to pre pandemic levels but that didn't happen, they only kept going up, PC gaming included.

So, cross your fingers I guess, you're living through the modern day equivalent of the middle ages where rich nobles ruled everything.

comments.text:
If they are intentionally doing something to inflate the prices then they are Price fixing.  

Price fixing in the United States is illegal and can be prosecuted under the Sherman Antitrust Act. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the Department of Justice (DOJ) are responsible for investigating and prosecuting price fixing. 
How is price fixing defined? 
Price fixing is an agreement between competitors to raise, lower, maintain, or stabilize prices
It can also include restricting production, sales, or output
Price fixing can be written, verbal, inferred from conduct, or worked out in secret
What are the penalties?
Individuals can be fined up to $1 million or imprisoned for up to 10 years 
Corporations can be fined up to $100 million 
Penalties can also include civil enforcement actions by the FTC 
How is price fixing detected? 
Price fixing can be difficult to detect because it can look like normal price adjustments in response to market pressures
Antitrust enforcers can try to detect and investigate markets with unexplainable supracompetitive prices

TLDR: Nvidia has laid out the red carpet for AMD. Fingers crossed that they deliver.

comments.text: I have the money to afford all this but to me it's starting to look like it's no worth it.  Just because I have the money, it doesn't mean I'm just going to give it away.  To add insult to injury, PC games seem to need way more GPU horsepower to generate similar results to consoles.  It used to be that if you had a descent card you could run the same games than console but at way higher framerates and resolution.  Now a days it seems that some games need a 4080 and DLSS performance to render the game at 1080p and then upscale it to 4k in order to get 60, the same as consoles.  I think my current PC is the last dedicated gaming machine I build and I'm going full Playstation from now on.  No more jumping through hoops for the privilege of finding a decent GPU to pay thousands of dollars for it, to later have  games stutter like crazy and on top of that maybe having a fire hazard under my TV. And before people start commenting that I will have to pay much more for games, that is BS. I have a PS3 and a PS4 and I never payed more than $30 for any games. Like on PC you just don't buy on release and buy months later during sales.

hey Jay and team, thanks for the excelent video and honesty on it, GPUs and most PC hardware is getting out of reach for most of us, the only solution for this is for us the consumers to stop spending on unnecessary hardware, don't get me wrong, i love FPS i love to crank a game to the highest detail, but at these prices is not affordable or even smart to do it.

Something that gets the job done, with recent hardware (4000 RTX series/7000 AMD series, but not the high end), new hardware just not the newest, no extras, no 4k anything, maybe 1080p, maximum 1440p monitors as those have become more affordable, not even the highest detail possible, we know 60fps is "enough" is good to have more but 60 is "good enough".

comments.text: This video just further confirms what Linus said on the wan show a few weeks back about card reviews basically don’t matter. Most people that will buy the card don’t watch them, most of the ones that do are just there for the performance numbers and don’t listen to the reviewers, and the small subset that are left have no effect on the market. It is truly sad to see cards that are barely better than last gen getting price so much higher than their predecessors and people continue to buy them in droves without a care. AMD won’t fix the gpu market they’ll only feed into like every other time, and if they don’t it just means their cards can’t keep up and they know it. I have some hope for intel but with the driver overhead issues those cards can’t be recommended for anyone who isn’t on AM5 or LGA1700 and later. It is truly sad to be a pc gamer now and I can’t fault anyone for going to buy a console at this point. I had planned to upgrade from my 3080 10gb this gen but honestly even the 5070 ti at it’s actual price is going to be probably a bit to rich for me. comments.text:
I mean, even if they sell these 5070s for $1500, you can bet your life that all stocks would be gone within a couple of minutes from all retailers and online stores. You can't even buy 4xxx series card anymore.. 

Of course, this wouldn't be the case if there's a million of these 5xxx cards that are available right now. But nope, they only made 100 of these cards so far and the 1M or so people all around the world who want these cards would either have to click the store page for 24x7 everyday or enter and win a lottery from NewEgg or other stores to earn the right to buy these cards.

The shortage. fits the law of supply and demand. So it's natural any company would take advantage of the situation! 
Pretty soon, companies would offer VIP memberships you need to pay for or subscribe annually so that you will get special preference and priority to buy new products or reserve stocks. and yup, millions of Americans would be happy to subscribe to or pay for such a service! 

It's capitalism pure and simple!

comments.text: Maybe the answer is to just start treating Team Green as if they've sent you a product for a different channel entirely. If these are AI cards that you can also game on, treat it as if someone asked you to review their new blender or washing machine. Send it back and remind them what kind of channel you run. If it was a gaming card, it'd have a more competitive price point and more VRAM. Clearly it was made for something else. I mean I can use my washing machine to mix margaritas... and that'd make about as much sense as this card launch has. If Team Red launches a similar product line, make them also find a dedicated AI channel to run glow ups on. It could be that Intel launched the only actual gaming cards this year. It'd be kind of a crappy year for gaming if that's the case, but it'd be an honest point to make. "Well, we've gotta wait for the 60 series or whatever AMD launches and hope they both decide to get back into gaming again." At this point, even doing benchmark comparisons on these cards is kind of like making videos on the towing capacity of the latest Honda Accord.

comments.text:
That's what you get when people that are not gamers and they don't care about gamers, make GPUs. This is my favorite hobby and i cannot enjoy it anymore. I'm stuck with a GTX 1070 for eight years now and i cannot change it, because GPUs are equivalent to cars now pricewise and games play like SH*T on that. The result? I've stopped playing AAA games that came out after 2020 and only play recent games when they have shitty graphics. So it's either replaying old games (i must've finished Subnautica a thousand times in the last couple of years), or crappy new ones.

They have introduced "new and innovative" technologies in games, like Ray Tracing and Path Tracing, which with traditional rendering take hours for ONE frame to render and because (of course) the GPUs could not handle the load, they said "you know what? We'll let AI give you FAKE frames. Problem solved!. Oh, and we'll add a thousand bucks to the GPU price for it. We hope you're ok with that!". Well, me, as a gamer am NOT ok with that at all. You can take Ray Tracing and Path Tracing and shove it up you know were. I don't need my games to look like real life, when half of it is fake and also costs a fortune. Remove demanding visual tech and make GPUs with only raw power again. Graphics can't improve before the GPUs. GPUs must improve first, to then handle heavier loads.

comments.text:
Jay thats not how Inflation works Bruv. 
That's a convenient argument of Corporate Indoctrination. 
Inflation demands Matching of Pricing to Paycheck to Equalize Buying power. 
Let me Give you an Example
In 2017 1080Ti came out. at $699
$1 in 2017 is $1.28 NOW. Thats 28% Inflation. 
But Average paycheck Went up in the US by 12-14% from 2017-2025 So let's say Your Paycheck From 2017 of 1000 USD has to be 1280 USD to retain the Buying power. But your real Paycheck is 1140 USD. All this is according to US Inflation calculator, and INDEPENDENT Pay data.
 
The 1080Ti has to cost $803 adjusted for inflation we have now. 
The best we Have Now is FE 5090 at Hopefully $1999
So even if you were to argue Inflation $1999 is 249% of $803. Thats 149% increase on MSRP

But let's pretend 1080Ti is not worthy of God's melty touch that the 5090 is and we take the 5080.
$999 is 124% of $803 and 803 is already adjusted for Inflation previously. 
So that's Inflation on Inflation. 24% additional on 28% Inflation. 

But the Paychecks are 16% less Then they should be to account for Inflation of 28%.
What inflation are you people taking about FFS?
C'mon m8...
If you Use US government census Data average Salary in 2017 was $60.336
In 2025 that Number is $59,436
Inflation me that...
That's $900 before the Inflation or Adjusted for Inflation $1152 you get less, now, than in 2017 for doing the same job.
That I believe is a 5080 MSRP you get Less per Year of Work, But the 80 class card costs 24% more after You adjusted the 2017 card for Inflation. 
So Again What inflation are you talking about. 
During inflation Prices go up because PEOPLE HAVE MORE MONEY, so Money IS WORTH LESS.
BUT PEOPLE HAVE LESS MONEY NOW.
What even the Fuck is wrong with Y'all.
God the corporate indoctrination is Mad effective...

I'm moving to gaming on emulation and old school consoles.  I'm done buying these insane priced GPU's.  And understand that I could.  I spent just north of 2 grand on a 3090FE back in 2021 because I was replacing a 7 year old PC.  I didn't like it but I did it.  But the prices since 2020 have gotten out of hand and I'm done playing this game.  I honestly don't give a single crap who is at fault.  I stop caring about pointing fingers about things years ago.  The fact it someone is causing this price creep.  
I'm going to play Switch/PSX2-3/GameCube/Dreamcast/PSX/N64/Saturn/SNES/Genesis/GameBoy/SNK/MAME.  That is a crap ton of content that just needs a solid CPU.  GPU less so and even then my 3090 FE can handle it.  I'm just f*ck'n done with this crap.  Thanks NVIDIA et al.  I have a GeForce 256 on my shelf. comments.text:
The only way AMD is going to gain immediate market share is if they out price Nvidia.. This is exactly how they started laying the pain on Intel. They dropped the Ryzen R7 1800 in 2017 for £500 (that then went down to £350 and below). This was the main competitor to Intel's i7 6900K CPU which sold for £1100.. Fast forward seven years later and Intel; the once absolute CPU "Alpha" is throwing up in the back alley due to alcoholic issues, wife has walked out with the dog, etc..

£500 vs £1100... Checkmate... This is what they need to do to bring the pain to Nvidia like they did to Intel.. That 9070XT needs to perform like a 7900XTX and then have to sell it for £500... Checkmate and 50% market share and PC gamer's goodwill within two years. After that, they can resume competing on a cost for cost, GPU tier for tier with those next gen chips (where they will compete for the enthusiast's tier).

Hopefully by that time the AI bubble would have burst and Nvidia, no longer a trillion dollar company, suddenly realises how much they "annoyed" PCMR (to put that lightly).. Prices come back down again across the board and PC gamers can be happy once more with proper competition in the GPU markets. Hey, maybe even Intel might have their hat in the ring..

comments.text:
I think we can agree that even with inflation, increased costs of production etc. - launching card like this (16G VRAM) for 500-600$ is completely doable. And differences would be most seen in coolers. I'd prefer 100$ less for card if it runs 5C warmer (as long as it's 85C let's say) and 2 dBA louder. But I'm odd, I don't mind little noise, because there is a lot of noisy stuff here.
Coolers became overengineered to look "cool" and provide the best thermals and noise. Which is great. I'm not saying I want dinky 40mm fan on the CPU core. But there should be middle ground.
Situation is similar to mobos. 10 years ago VRM quality was..... varied. Now almost every board comes with VRM that could support 2 overclocked CPU's from 14th Gen. Some restraint would be useful. "Middle-range" is the word.

And of course it's not just coolers that increased price of GPU's. Main driver (heh) of the elevated prices is NVIDIA. Because they control the market. Cryptos would buy in bulk for much more than average user would buy. AI now buys for a lot more than average person would buy? So why would they even care? How much do they care? New connector shows how much.

comments.author: @frankymac338

comments.text: I understand scalping with GPUs is possible because of high demand, limited supply, and inadequate control over distribution. While it may seem like other companies can manage this better, Nvidia and AMD face a unique set of challenges, especially when global supply chains and sudden surges in demand are involved. It would take a more coordinated effort across the entire industry to stop scalping, something that Apple has managed better due to its control over its ecosystem. However still I dont understand why AMD and NVIDIA dont try to manage distribution through things like limiting the number of items sold per customer ect

comments.text:
Jay speaking the truth. I bought my 3090 just before the 40 series came out at £900ish (UK) and have been in awe of the raw power even at that price point. I knew I'd skip the 40 series, now I'm 100% skipping the 50 series seeing all the news on the inflated costs, so now I'll probably be skipping to an all AMD build in a few years in this Nvidia rich boy trend continues.

Consoles always had their place in PC gaming during the 90's and 00's as a reasonible cost-performance trend, I can only think things are swinging back that way this decade (if mostly Playstation). Realistically I see Xbox leaving at the end of this generation and it being a Switch 2 vs PS5/6 'battle' in a almost non aggressive way due to their respective approaches on the tech. The key is at this point, I believe 'the masses' to be more into that approach rather than hardcore PC gaming at a cost point where a 5090 costs the same as 3 PS5 pro's. It just seems like the latest cost increases remind me of that era.

Also JAY! we'd love to see some more builds from you. How about doing something 'retro'. Example an all in one 90's or 00's build with older consoles like the Mega Drive/Genesis and SNES with modern tech enthused inside it. It might unleash your creative side and allow you not to focus on the PC side that is atm a bit overwhelming due to the state of play atm. Just a thought man!

comments.text:
DLSS is on 40 cards. Does it run as well on them as the 50s? Yes, the 4090 is a hot card; it’s a fact that it runs hotter than a 4080 and 5080. That’s not a lie, and you’re speaking from right now about MFG. I’m not. I’m speaking about the future the same way DLSS didn’t start off running great on many games. You can see multiple videos comparing 2 to 4, and 2 doesn’t look as good and has more artifacts. The tech wasn’t made to be only a short-term thing, which is why you’re saying how MFG isn’t running well on multiple games now. That doesn’t make any sense. It will be better in the future. This means a person who plans on keeping their card for a while, like people who still have a 3080 like me, will be able to take advantage of MFG in the future. That means they will still be able to use their card 3 or 4 years later. They’re not thinking about now; just because MFG isn’t great in many games now doesn’t mean it won’t be in the future, you know, as if you’re looking at it for some odd reason.
So I looked up earlier benchmarks in 4K. The 4070 Ti is on average compared to the S version only 7 FPS faster. Sometimes games can show a 15 FPS jump, some can show a 10 FPS jump, but then jumping from a 4070 Ti shows an average 36 FPS jump in some games. So that's more like what we will see from the 5070 Ti and 5080; it will be like a 36 FPS average less than the 5080. If we get an S version of the 5070 Ti, that will be closer to the 5080, just as the 4070 Ti is closer to the 4080.
comments.author: @cjo9966

comments.text:
Surely all the bench marks for the 50 series are out off whack.  what I mean is is with DLSS 4 all existing older series cards capable off using DLSS 4 are already getting a 10%-15% minimum boost.   So surely the reality should be that for an upgrade to 50 series card you would be looking for a performance improvement in and around 40% for it even to be a consideration.
  The way I see it is NVIDIA have done little to actually improve the hardware but relied on a software hack to justify these prices.
     If NVIDIA had doubled the VRAMM  on all its newer models that would have been a far bigger justification  for people to accept the crazy pricing despite the hardware performance not dramatically increasing.  Their marketing department really dropped the ball on this series.
     I am hoping that all the other companies other than NVIDIA will see this and maybe in a few months we  will be seeing 50 series cards with huge increases in VRAMM.  After all VRRAMM is pretty cheap for the manufactures,  and many people would justify spending  the $900+ price tags if they were getting double the VRAMM

comments.text: About 25 years ago I used to work for a really good company for 12-13 years, then it got bought out and started to run like your typical corporation. It used to be that competition was good for pricing, where they would have to lower prices to compete with others. It's not like that anymore. Now it's waiting for the first to release to see what price they can match to. We have the same issue here in Canada with food at the grocery stores. They used to compete for lower prices. Now they just keep raising prices because they know people will buy it and the others will match. We are being led by greed and are forced into this new norm. Higher prices are everywhere, but our income doesn't match the inflation. It will hit a wall eventually.

For graphics we'll see lesser people buying games with extreme graphical needs because we are not able to afford the new prices to run them and when the game developers slow down on improving visuals to keep the video power down, less people will have to buy these over prices cards. Dunno, just trying to make sense out of something that makes no sense... Maybe Intel will be the hero someday being they don't really have anything to lose at the moment and be able to compete at the high-end GPU level.

comments.text: I really think it's time we start to accept that gpu prices are never going back to "normal". This is the new normal. For those who can, it may be time to consider other options as their main way to game, like portables (steam deck, etc) and AMD's other iGPU solutions. Or heck, even consoles. Some games on console have keyboard and mouse support. Basically, it's time to start thinking outside of the box and embracing some of these other solutions for those who only game and don't need workstation power for other tasks. I've been waiting for prices to go back to normal. That's never going to happen. People keep paying these prices so there's no incentive for them to charge less. At $749, this one isn't a terrible price in the context of a 4080/4080 super, but broadly speaking $749 is insane in general and has been since this kinda pricing was introduced. That kinda cash not long ago got you the top tier and then some.

comments.text: QUESTION JAY. What GPU would you recommend if this is "not worth it"? You say Price I say "investment" what I focus on is the best (lowest) cost per month until my next upgrade. My personal minimum standards are 144fps at 1440p in the games i play and I upgrade based on this and really everyone should set their minimum standard and invest in hardware based on that. FACT is the GPU market and price isn't EVER going down and so you need to INVEST smart. If your currently on a 10xx series or even 20xx series of course wait for AMD's offerings but i think the 5xxx series will be the best value over time proposition if you NEED an upgrade. So far looking at the numbers for my minimum standards im thinking the 5080 would be the best investment that will push out my next upgrade date as far as possible and lowering my final cost per month cost (i can afford it but i don't need it yet technically). Here's my past. I bought the 1080 at release for $800CAD and I upgraded to the 3090 at release for $1900 (52 months). My cost on that 1080 was aproxx $15.40 a month in the end. Assuming I upgrade in the 6xxx series guessing Q4 Dec ish 2026 which is likely when i will upgrade, the cost for my 3090 will be $25.33 per month in the end (some guessing there but it'll be in that range)

My desktop from 2015 is still rocking a GTX 970. The laptop I'm currently using (bought for travel use but it ended up being better than my old desktop) is using a 1660ti Mobile. I have the money to build a new desktop now and have been wanting to, but the entire new PC, sans Video Card, is going to run me roughly $1K.

I am not willing to pay the price of an entire second PC for one component. Period. My GTX 970 was less than $400 and the entire PC (including that GPU) based around an i7 4790k was barely $1,400. Bring back those days. I know it's basically impossible, the economy has changed too much. But if you ask me, the 5090 should be the $1,000 - 1,200 card. The 5080 should be the $750 - 850 card. The 5070 ti the $650 - 750 card. The 5070 the $550 - 600. The 5060 and such somewhere below that. This is all of course assuming any of these cards actually brought performance above the last generation that actually made them attractive options.

comments.text:
In November 2023 I bought my 16GB XFX Radeon Speedster Merc 6950XT brand new from a retailer for £570. I bought it because I only care about the pure rasterization performance. I still mostly play COD Warzone with my friends once a week on 1440p high resolution settings and the framerate target is set to 165fps as that pretty much maxes out my monitor's output and eliminates the chance for any sudden frame drops during the gaming session.

At that time, this seemed like an expensive buy but good enough deal compared to the horrendous pricing for nvidia's 40 series and AMD'S 70 series cards, which were at that time the newest generation. 

Now - fast forward 2025. It's probably getting even worse if we talk about the pricing. 4070ti - a mid tier graphics card, in my eyes, costs a grand? That is just insane! I recently bought a mk4 volkswagen golf for £600 that I am now using as my work vehicle and here we are talking about the graphics card that is almost double the price that I paid for a set of wheels that will actually allow me to make income. 😅

Bottom line - I know for sure that I definitely won't be upgrading my PC for a few good years. Screw the big companies that haven't yet woken up and realised that the crypto minig boom is over, lockdowns are no longer a thing, and that there's no more chip shortages!

comments.text: what is the difference between profit and revenue?
comments.author: @seisoch6969

comments.text: @seisoch6969  Revenue is the total amount of money brought in by the company. Profit is the amount of money they made subtracting their expenses.
comments.author: @icy1007

comments.text: @seisoch6969  revenue is the sales price, so pretty much what you see as the price on the shelf (sort of, it's more like that a place like microcenter pays Nvidia for the cards).  Profit is the number you get after you subtract all the expenses, including taxes, payroll, r&d, everything at the end of the year.  The ratio of net profit to revenue is profit margin, in the form of a %.  For a place like, Walmart, they're usually at 3% profit margin, meaning if they sell $100 of product, they keep $3 of it at the end of the year.  Nvidia's for that quarter was something like 50%.
comments.author: @chucklestheclwn5996

Today, I'd think a good chunk of desktop builds that aren't dedicated to gaming must be relying on cheaper AMD products or iGPUs. I also wouldn't bet that nvidia's doing its best margin or benefits on entry-level products such as 50/Ti models, even if they sold orders of magnitude more than flagship products. I mean you can technically run even modern pc games on older gaming pc hardware from few gens back. Its just that if you want the best out of modern games, as you would of course, you need to have a powerful and thus quite expensive gaming pc. And preferably a large expensive good gaming monitor or pc gaming suitable tv. Otherwise whats the point. Like its not fun playing a modern game with lowest settings and upscaled from whatever res to 1080p at 40-60hz. 

Really the minimum from gpu side of things for proper modern gaming is basically starting from 700-1000 euros product. And if you want to have better fun out of your gaming, then you put a thousand or couple of thousands euros more for the gpu. And you probably do that every other generation to stay at good gaming performance level. Along with upgrading the rest of the gaming pc. 

Starts to add up to a point that other hobbies and interests are possible with such costs. Hobbies where you are not limited to sitting in your room and imagining these cool places and cool people. Probably much more fun and beneficial hobbies to be had with such constant investments. Like i dont know, ice hockey or traveling or something. Really almost anything where you actually go to different places and see and meet actual different people. Or i guess to gamers they are different maps and characters. But still.

The video game industry will die, but video games will survive. The multibillion dollar video game studio conglomerate model will serve a smaller and smaller market of “current gen” consumers, and eventually collapse. However…

comments.text:
@Rdwini  Yeah. I remember that "PhysX" setting in Arkham City that, when enable, would make my game run like a slideshow. Even if I had a dedicated nVidia GPU when it came out.
Or a newer midrange AMD GPU when playin it again recenlty.

Or disable the settings and just play the game. So no, they don't "run on PhysX". They have it as an extra feature. If you had the correct hardware.


You can still run it in software mode, BTW. Or on a dedicated older GPU when you really have the itch to play a 15 years old game. Or drop that community .dll that's gonna fix the issue in a few months (because it's a driver deprecation, not an hardware one).

Literally a non issue if you really are into PC Gaming: Compatibilities for older APIs and function gets deprecated with time. Try running a Glide game without wrapper or a 3DNow! game on a ryzen CPU without community fixes.

Backwards compatibility on PCs has laways been iffy at best if you've been into this hobby as long as I have, at least (so make it almost 25 years).

comments.text:
@planexshifter  "Your old cards suddenly didn’t go bad".
Not instantly, but of course they are and already were for many of us already skipped at least the last generation of GPU because of the corporate greed, shenanigans and/or incompetence. Now they are doing the same of even worse for this gen. It's horrible.
Games and apps aren't sticking with the same performance requirements just because Nvidia is screwing gamers.
In fact games have been getting disproportionately more power hungry and worse optimised because of relying upon recent versions of hardware/software/drivers to work 'well'.
Eventually we will have to upgrade, but how much worse will consumers be being treated by then? I'm sure 60 series will be awesome and Nvidia changed it ways...
Currently I really wish I'd bought a 40 series, once we'd worked out how to stop them melting and prices had normalised and guess what, Nvidia intentionally stopped that from happening in order to sell the new gen and keep providing to data centres.
So "what the fuck is wrong" (but not with everyone, unfortunately - the dumb-assed average modern consumer is desperate for the chance for Nvidia to treat them like morons) is we want to continue the hobby we've been enjoying for years (decades, some of us) and, funnily enough, don't want to be conned to do it.
We want companies to behave as if their customers matter, especially the ones who helped build their business ("betrayal" is what it is).
We want other consumers to stop excusing and encouraging Nvidia and other corps to treat us like drooling morons with more money than sense.
"Businesses have to make a profit". Yes. But they don't have to do it by shafting their customers. They really don't. And they shouldn't get away with it, never mind be encouraged.

comments.text:
@planexshifter It is not about "old" card going bad, but that sooner or later one have to upgrade and then you will have a major issue to find anything that are reasonable priced.

When I started to think about upgrading my i5  4670K and GTX 970 which I had used for almost a decade (build in around 2014) price on GTX 1080 TI (in 2018) just went up first in  because of being almost out of stock when it was "cheap" and then you had competition from  crypto miners. 

Due to different reason I had to post pone my build and suddenly we where at 2023 when RTX 40 series card (and AMDs 7900XT(X)) where launched. 

At same time stock on RTX 30 series card where non-existence as Nvidia had stopped producing those card long time before release of RTX 40 series card and same for AMDs 6950 XT which where replaced with 7900 series card (and those card where also few at launch which means that after first batch where sold price went up).

In the end I ended up with RTX 4070 TI (Super didn't exist at that time in Januar 2023) and had to pay around 11 000 SEK for that card as price where not going down and I had already been waiting on prices to become more reasonable for "older cards" which instead where out of stock or increased when they where restocked.

To sum it up: it is a gamble where purchasing hardware now instead is to risk that you end up to pay very much more then you intended when you started to plan on building a new computer.

Don't forget how motherboards pricing have also increased over time since 2014 where you get one for 700 SEK that was decent and not the cheapest one where you could end up with failure due to cheap components (yes there where caps that leaked etc at that time).

comments.text:
​ @thelespauldude3283   The AI division operates separately from the gaming division, though they share the same company. The AI side generated $30 billion, while the gaming division made $3.3 billion—nearly 10 times less. The two divisions do not directly affect each other, except possibly in inventory management, as they share fabrication space with other chipmakers, potentially limiting the production of both AI and gaming chips (allegedly).

The primary issue in the high-end GPU market is the lack of competition. With AMD stepping away from that segment—based on solid reasoning—Nvidia remains uncontested. This allows Nvidia to release incremental upgrades at high prices without significant pressure. While some might argue this creates a monopoly, AMD and Intel still compete in the broader GPU market.

AMD’s decision to exit the high-end space is based on the reality that enthusiast buyers overwhelmingly choose Nvidia regardless of alternatives. Instead, AMD is focusing on mid-range GPUs, catering to the average gamer by improving efficiency and increasing market share where it can compete effectively. Given that AMD’s GPU division lacks the same resources as Nvidia’s, this strategy is a logical pivot.

comments.text:
Every developer and AI tinkerer is desperately wanting NVIDIA cards also.  And many of them won't already have a two year old high end GPU to start with. 

There is close to zero price effect to be had from a gamer boycott.  It will just make cards more available to people who will use them to make money (solo and small team developers, and content creators, etc).

So far, NVIDIA is the only option for these folk, and they need maximum RAM on their GPUs. 
They don't even need half the functionality that a GPU has (e.g. raytracing math) and probably won't even connect a monitor. 

The only solution I can see is for desktop level NPUs to come available, so that (mainly) hobby gamers aren't fighting it out at the stores with (mostly) professional and semi-professional and wannabe professional developers and others who's only option right now is NVIDIA GPUs with lots of vRAM.

Meanwhile, the only thing NVIDIA needs to care about right now is continuing to market cards to gamers, so that they still retain pole position in the gaming market when desktop PCIe AI accelerators (NPUs) finally arrive to properly split out this distinct market, who have a different technical requirement and generally more dollars to spend.

comments.text:
Part of the issue is that if gamers stop buying these consumer GPUs from NVidia, they’ll probably just discontinue them altogether. NVidia’s consumer GPUs make a tiny portion of their total market share, with ML products taking a much more substantial portion. 

If NVidia stops making consumer cards, then we just have AMD and Intel, which will drive those prices up with less competition between the two and both sides would be less likely to produce actual innovation over the previous model besides more transistors, pipelines, and VRAM. It sucks that it has to be this way, because even lower end RTX cards can be quite powerful for running local LLMs, but if NVidia stops consumer card production, then local AI becomes less available to consumers.

I don’t like that things are the way they are, but until AMD and Intel have more competitive performance (more recent RX cards are quite good, but still lacking for RayTracing performance and ROCm support), for substantially less money, NVidia is just going to push further and further from realistic pricing, production, and substantial innovation (DLSS aside). :(
